section: a line of vertical Gneiss runs <s>along<\s> due North along each of the high ridges of hills between Loch
Eil-head and Loch Sheil, and  <s>the ar<\s> between these
the foliation <s>is much contorted & inclined at high
angle and highly in<\s>  is highly inclined and
much contorted, forming with the perpendiculars
several of the fan-like arrangements before
alluded to. Westward of Glen Finnen also the Gneiss
is vertical on several lines <s>with
<\s> gradually
changing in direction as we go westward from
N5E to N20E which last is the prevailing
strike in that district. In taking a broad
view of the phenomena we must regard <s>all<\s>
these lines of vertical foliation as constituting
one band. <s>which<\s>
The next traverse <s>which I<\s>  made was
from Fort Augustus to Glenelg along Glen
Morrison and Glen Shiel: several lines of perpen-
dicular Gneiss cross this road in the high
region which separates the waters of the Shiel
& the Clunie, viz. one <s>viz<\s> at the head of Loch Clunie
striking N30E; again at the Clunie inn on the
top of the pass with the same strike, & another
a mile down Glen Shiel striking North: the
prevailing direction is here N30E.
On Loch Linchart the Gneiss is vertical
both at the head of the Loch & at the village of
Garve, with a direction of N45E which
